headline.main: REAGAN, IN BRAZIL, WARNS ON TRADE

results.snippet: President Reagan warned an audience of United States and Brazilian business leaders today that the global trend toward trade barriers and protectionism would lead to ''economic contraction and eventually dangerous instability'' in the Western...
results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan warned an audience of United States and Brazilian business leaders today that the global trend toward trade barriers and protectionism would lead to ''economic contraction and eventually dangerous instability'' in the Western Hemisphere and the developing world. In his second and final full day in Brazil, Mr. Reagan flew from Brasilia in the interior to the nation's industrial and financial center to deliver a familiar appeal for free trade and free enterprise unfettered by government controls. Mr. Reagan did not refer to any specific trade disputes with Brazil. The two main ones have been over Brazil's practice of subsidizing exports and the United States effort to lower barriers to international trade in banking, insurance and other services areas. Brazil has led the fight against such a move.

headline.main: AIDES STUDYING OMENS FOR RE-ELECTING REAGAN

results.snippet: Fresh after Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1984 Presidential race, some of President Reagan's political associates are working to nudge the President into an early decision to run for re-election.   One group of Reagan political...

byline.original: By HEDRICK SMITH, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Fresh after Senator Edward M. Kennedy's withdrawal from the 1984 Presidential race, some of President Reagan's political associates are working to nudge the President into an early decision to run for re-election. One group of Reagan political aides led by Lyn Nofziger, former White House political director who is now a private consultant, will meet Monday in suburban Virginia for what is described as a preliminary planning session for a re-election campaign. But most of the President's top strategists will be absent. The President's polling consultant, Richard Wirthlin, who is among those invited to the planning session, told reporters today he believed that if the President had to decide now, his decision would be to run again and that an early decision would help his chances. Mr. Wirthlin also contended that even if the economy was in ''pretty rough'' shape in 1984, the President could win re-election if key trends were improving.

results.snippet: President Reagan and his weary staff were on the way from Brasilia to Bogota on Friday morning when they received word from the United States Embassy that Colombia's new President, Belisario Betancur, planned to assail the United States in his...

byline.original: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: President Reagan and his weary staff were on the way from Brasilia to Bogota on Friday morning when they received word from the United States Embassy that Colombia's new President, Belisario Betancur, planned to assail the United States in his public remarks. The staff was in a tizzy. How should Mr. Reagan respond? According to those who were there, the President had a simple answer: ''We should smother him with love.'' It was a telling moment, because the overriding impression of Mr. Reagan's arduous 15,000-mile trip to Latin America, which ended Saturday night, was of a man seeking to project his personality on to countries that he and others knew had histories of distrust of United States motives.

headline.main: SOVIET CREW RETURNS TO EARTH AFTER SETTING RECORD IN SPACE

results.snippet: The Soviet astronauts Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev returned safely to earth tonight after a record 211 days in orbit, the official press agency Tass reported.   The men uncoupled their Soyuz T-7 spacecraft from the orbiting Salyut 7 space...
results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet astronauts Anatoly Berezovoy and Valentin Lebedev returned safely to earth tonight after a record 211 days in orbit, the official press agency Tass reported. The men uncoupled their Soyuz T-7 spacecraft from the orbiting Salyut 7 space station and landed about two and a half hours later, at 10:03 P.M. Moscow time, Tass said. Soviet radio and television said the descent module landed in the dark in flat steppe country 110 miles east of the town of Dzhezkazgan in Kazakhstan in central Asia. A lighthouse equipped with a strong beam was installed at the site to guide helicopters with ground crews to assist the astronauts.

headline.main: FOR CHRISTMAS GIFTS, 700 RAG DOLLS FOR THE NEEDY

results.snippet: Any Santa Claus worth a ho-ho-ho knows that, at a certain age, one doll is worth a sackful of sables and diamonds. True, dolls aren't as hockable, but would anyone be so crass as to hock Jacques the wilderness adventurer, Etthen-Oolah the Eskimo,...
results.lead_paragraph: Any Santa Claus worth a ho-ho-ho knows that, at a certain age, one doll is worth a sackful of sables and diamonds. True, dolls aren't as hockable, but would anyone be so crass as to hock Jacques the wilderness adventurer, Etthen-Oolah the Eskimo, Nicole the roller skater or Flapper Beth? These little creatures, and some 700 others, are rag dolls, each with a distinctive personality but all made from the same basic pattern. They arrived in New York in the last month from every state in the Union, as well as from Puerto Rico, Canada, Zimbabwe, Turkey and Trinidad, in response to a ''Santa's Helper'' contest sponsored by McCall's Needlework and Crafts Magazine. And on Christmas morning, the Children's Aid Society will distribute them to boys and girls who might otherwise be without gifts.

headline.main: DOCTORS TO JOIN SHUTTLE CREWS TO MONITOR MOTION SICKNESS

results.snippet: A doctor will be added to two space shuttle flights next year to monitor the crew and to find ways to alleviate what the National Aeronautics and Space Administration calls ''space adaption syndrome.''   ''You could call it 'space sickness' or...
results.lead_paragraph: A doctor will be added to two space shuttle flights next year to monitor the crew and to find ways to alleviate what the National Aeronautics and Space Administration calls ''space adaption syndrome.'' ''You could call it 'space sickness' or 'space motion sickness,' '' David Alter, a space agency spokesman, said today. Astronauts have experienced nausea, loss of appetite, drowsiness and cold sweats since the earliest days of manned space flight, especially in spacecraft with enough room for them to move about while in orbit. ''It's not so serious that you're incapacitated,'' said Mr. Alter. ''It's a malaise, not feeling well without specific complaint, perhaps a headache, the nausea and appetite loss.''

results.snippet: James Lovell, the United States astronaut, fractured his upper arm and shoulder while skiing and is being flown back to the United States for medical treatment, the Austrian Press Agency reported today.
results.lead_paragraph: James Lovell, the United States astronaut, fractured his upper arm and shoulder while skiing and is being flown back to the United States for medical treatment, the Austrian Press Agency reported today.

results.snippet: International Lebanon and Israel opened talks designed to bring about a withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanese soil. Israel also hopes that the negotiations, being held outside Beirut amid tight security, will pave the...
results.lead_paragraph: International Lebanon and Israel opened talks designed to bring about a withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanese soil. Israel also hopes that the negotiations, being held outside Beirut amid tight security, will pave the way for an Israeli-Lebanese peace treaty. (Page A1, Column 1.) Ethnic tension among Israeli Jews has re-emerged over the fatal shooting of a man by a policeman in a housing dispute. The shooting occurred in a Tel Aviv slum dominated by Sephardic Jews from Middle Eastern countries. Officials have received threats, and swastikas and slogans against Ashkenazim, or Jews of European stock, have been spray-painted on cars and buildings in affluent sectors of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem. (A7:1.)

headline.main: JACK SWIGERT, ASTRONAUT ELECTED TO CONGRESS, DIES

results.snippet: Jack Swigert, a former astronaut from Colorado who was elected to the House of Representatives in November while suffering from cancer, died Monday night at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 51 years old.   Mr. Swigert, a...
results.lead_paragraph: Jack Swigert, a former astronaut from Colorado who was elected to the House of Representatives in November while suffering from cancer, died Monday night at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 51 years old. Mr. Swigert, a Republican who was described by a campaign supporter as ''a potent advocate for Ronald Reagan, a certified hero with a brain,'' had been flown to the cancer center a week earlier from his home in Littleton, Colo. He died of respiratory failure.

results.snippet: ASTRONAUT'S BODY FLOWN TO DENVER: The coffin containing the body of Jack Swigert, an astronaut on Apollo 13 and a newly elected Congressman, being loaded onto an Air Force jet yesterday in Washington. Mr. Swigert died of cancer Monday at Georgetown...
results.lead_paragraph: ASTRONAUT'S BODY FLOWN TO DENVER: The coffin containing the body of Jack Swigert, an astronaut on Apollo 13 and a newly elected Congressman, being loaded onto an Air Force jet yesterday in Washington. Mr. Swigert died of cancer Monday at Georgetown University Hospital. He is to be buried Tuesday in Denver.
